testTitle: Life in the UK Test - Government & Law
testDescription: Advanced test covering UK government structure, legal system, democratic processes, and citizenship responsibilities.

questions.stem: How often must a General Election be held in the UK?
questions.explanation: Under the Fixed-term Parliaments Act 2011, General Elections must be held at least every 5 years, though they can be called earlier under certain circumstances.

questions.stem: Which of these are duties of a UK citizen?

options.label: Serving on a jury when called

questions.explanation: UK citizens have legal duties to obey the law, pay taxes, and serve on juries when called. Voting is a right, not a legal duty.

questions.stem: The UK has a written constitution.
questions.explanation: The UK has an unwritten constitution. Its constitutional arrangements are based on a combination of laws, conventions, and traditions rather than a single written document.

questions.stem: Who is the Head of State in the UK?

options.label: The Speaker of the House of Commons

questions.explanation: The monarch (currently King Charles III) is the Head of State. The Prime Minister is the Head of Government. These are separate roles in the UK's constitutional monarchy.

questions.stem: What is the House of Lords?
questions.explanation: The House of Lords is the upper house of the UK Parliament. The House of Commons is the lower house. Together they make up the bicameral Parliament.

questions.stem: At what age can you legally buy alcohol in a pub in the UK?
questions.explanation: The legal age to buy and consume alcohol in pubs, bars, and shops in the UK is 18. However, 16-17 year olds can drink beer, wine, or cider with a meal in licensed premises when accompanied by an adult.

questions.stem: Which courts deal with serious criminal cases in England and Wales?
questions.explanation: Crown Courts deal with serious criminal cases in England and Wales. Magistrates' Courts handle less serious offences, while County Courts deal with civil matters.

questions.stem: What does 'devolution' mean in the UK context?

options.label: The transfer of power from central to regional governments
The process of leaving the European Union

questions.explanation: Devolution refers to the transfer of certain powers from the UK Parliament to the Scottish Parliament, Welsh Parliament, and Northern Ireland Assembly.

questions.stem: Members of Parliament (MPs) represent everyone in their constituency.
questions.explanation: MPs have a duty to represent all constituents in their area, regardless of how they voted or their political affiliation. This is a fundamental principle of UK democracy.

questions.stem: Which of these are principles of the UK legal system?

options.label: Everyone is equal under the law
Everyone has the right to a fair trial
You are innocent until proven guilty
The judge decides guilt or innocence in all cases

questions.explanation: Key principles include equality before the law, right to fair trial, and presumption of innocence. In serious criminal cases, a jury decides guilt, not the judge.

questions.stem: What is the role of the Prime Minister?
questions.explanation: The Prime Minister is the Head of Government and leads the political party with the most seats in the House of Commons. The monarch is the Head of State.
